message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the CT scan suggest that the patient has a renal calculus causing acute renal colic. Treatment usually involves hydration, pain management, and antiemetics. Hydrocodone and indomethacin can help manage pain in this situation. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy would be indicated if there was complete obstruction of the urinary tract or if there was infected hydronephrosis. 24-hour urine chemistry would be more appropriate for managing asymptomatic nephrolithiasis or recurrent stones. Lithotripsy could be a treatment option for larger stones, but not for the 4-mm-diameter stone in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of renal colic, and the CT scan has confirmed the presence of a stone. The next step in management should include pain control, which can be achieved with a combination of Hydrocodone and indomethacin. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy is not necessary at this time as the patient is still urinating normally. 24-hour urine chemistry can be ordered after the acute episode is resolved to identify potential causes for the nephrolithiasis. Lithotripsy may be considered for larger stones, but a 4mm-diameter stone can usually pass spontaneously with conservative management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the CT scan indicate acute renal colic caused by the ureteral stone. The initial management of acute renal colic includes pain management with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like indomethacin and opioids like hydrocodone. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy is only done in cases of obstructive uropathy or pyonephrosis. 24-hour urine chemistry can be done after initial management to identify the cause of nephrolithiasis. Lithotripsy may be considered if the stone is not passed spontaneously or if the patient has recurrent stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and CT findings indicate a kidney stone causing obstructive uropathy. Pain management with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (indomethacin) and opioids (hydrocodone) is the next best step. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy may be performed in cases of refractory pain or inability to tolerate oral medications, and lithotripsy may be necessary for larger stones or those that do not pass spontaneously. 24-hour urine chemistry may be helpful in determining the underlying cause of stone formation, but is not necessary in the acute management of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of renal colic, and the CT scan confirms the presence of a stone. Pain management is the next step, and options include opioids such as hydrocodone and a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug such as indomethacin. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy may be necessary if the patient is obstructed and septic, but this is not indicated in this case. 24-hour urine chemistry and lithotripsy may be considered later on in the management of nephrolithiasis but are not the next best step in the acute management of renal colic.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of renal colic, likely caused by the stone at the right ureteropelvic junction. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy may be necessary in certain cases, but the patient is stable and can be managed conservatively with pain control and hydration. Lithotripsy may be indicated if the stone does not pass spontaneously. A 24-hour urine chemistry can be obtained later to determine the patient's risk factors for stone formation. The next best step in the management of this patient is to provide pain relief with a combination of opioids and anti-inflammatory medication such as hydrocodone and indomethacin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, physical examination findings, and CT scan results suggest that he has a ureteral stone. The next best step in management is symptom relief, which can be achieved with pain control (hydrocodone) and anti-inflammatory medication (indomethacin). Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy or lithotripsy are not indicated at this time, and 24-hour urine chemistry may be needed for long-term prevention but is not necessary in the acute management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and imaging consistent with a ureteral stone causing acute renal colic. The next best step is to manage the pain with analgesics such as hydrocodone and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as indomethacin. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy and lithotripsy are not indicated in this case as the stone is small and is unlikely to cause significant obstruction. 24-hour urine chemistry is important to determine the metabolic risk factors that may be contributing to stone formation, however it is not the next best step in the acute management of this patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient likely has a kidney stone causing ureteral obstruction, which is causing severe pain and nausea. Initial management includes pain control with opioids and NSAIDs such as indomethacin. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy is not indicated at this time. 24-hour urine chemistry is useful in the evaluation of recurrent or complicated stones, but is not necessary in this acute management setting. Lithotripsy may be considered for stones that are larger in size or not expected to pass spontaneously, but is not necessary at this time as the stone is small and may pass spontaneously with appropriate medical management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and imaging suggest acute renal colic caused by an obstructing stone. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy is not necessary as the patient has mild hydronephrosis and can be managed conservatively. 24-hour urine chemistry can be obtained later for long-term management, but is not necessary for acute management. Lithotripsy can be considered for larger stones, but the 4-mm stone can likely pass spontaneously. The next best step is to manage the patient’s pain and nausea with a combination of hydrocodone and indomethacin, as well as continued hydration. If the stone does not pass, other options such as ureteroscopy or shockwave lithotripsy can be considered.
